greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Product of proper divisors of n.
comment: a(n) = 1 iff n = 1 or n is prime.
a(n) = n when n > 1 iff n has exactly four divisors, equally, iff n is either the cube of a prime or the product of two different primes, so iff n belongs to A030513 (very nice proof in Sierpiński).
As a(1) = 1, {1} Union A030513 = A007422, fixed points of this sequence. (End)
reference: Wacław Sierpiński, Elementary Theory of Numbers, Ex. 2 p. 174, Warsaw, 1964.
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (terms 1..1000 from T. D. Noe)
formula: a(n) = A007955(n)/n = n^(A000005(n)/2-1) = sqrt(n^(number of factors of n other than 1 and n)).
a(n) = A240694(n, A000005(n)-1) for n > 1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 10 2014
mathematica: a[n_] := n^(DivisorSigma[0, n]/2 - 1); Table[a[n], {n, 1, 65}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 07 2013 *)
program: (PARI) a(n)=my(k); if(issquare(n, &k), k^(numdiv(n)-2), n^(numdiv(n)/2-1)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Oct 15 2015
results.author: R. Muller
